children.subject: I don't really know what I'm talking about but I would guess that most of CS70 is actually more likely to be relevant for someone focusing on EE than someone focusing on CS.
IMO, CS70 is actually pretty useful for the math-heavy disciplines of EE (which honestly is most of them...). Personally, I wouldn't suggest delaying it too much.
One could also ask what makes CS interesting. The answer to both questions depends on whom you ask.
I'm genuinely curious why is OP in particular interested in EE?

OP: I actually just think EE is more interesting and exciting. I got into electronics and stuff like Arduino in high school. I didn't know that EECS was so CS-centered before I decided to come here, I think if I knew this, I would have probably gone somewhere else tbh. But that's not to say I'm not happy, Berkeley's EE department is world-class.

Not the OP, but as someone who focuses solely on EE, I enjoy creating and controlling working physical systems. Making say a SoC (system on Chip) actually work (and across all temperatures/environments- such as say inside the engine of a car, a toasty 200 degrees F,- and including account device variability, etc) offers an extra challenge I find rewarding.  It's also a "rich" field, encompassing many disciplines that have been studied since the 1890s- there's a reason for instance 126,127,120 etc are all "EE"- the concepts were all discovered by electrical engineers (mostly to solve wireless transmission problems)!
Why are you only focusing on EE? What about it is so interesting? (not a loaded question lol)

history.content:
I think that perhaps we need to actually explain to students why our requirements are required. 70 is absolutely core for essentially all sub-disciplines within EECS. At one point in the past, someone could have argued that perhaps it is not absolutely critical for folks interested only in device physics. But times have changed, and that is no longer true. 

Every course in the lower division simultaneously strengthens you in three broadly distinct ways: 

  • Maturity
  • Concepts and ways of thinking
  • Specific skills 

You might have noticed that I didn't even mention "Specific knowledge" because that is almost incidental in comparison to the importance of these three. The point of lifting a barbell isn't usually to lift a barbell, unless you are putting them away...

Students take both maturity and ways of thinking for granted, which I guess is a kind of success story because the whole point of education is to *transform you* and it natural that the changed you can no longer fully conceive of what you were like before. But this is arguably the most important part of the courses. This is why the department says to finish all your lower division before entering upper-div courses.

70 is the last course in the introductory information trilogy of 16A, 16B, 70. The concepts of probability are absolutely critical for anyone on the EE side, as are the ways of thinking developed vis-a-vis proofs via the multiple domains discussed before the probability side of the course. (In fact, you need the maturity and mental agility from that to have any chance of beginning to grasp probability in anything approaching good form. Otherwise, you risk leaning on formulas.)  70 could have been called EE70 and it wouldn't really be significantly different (maybe it would have a bit more modeling...) in the Berkeley context.

children.subject: Also about the annoying focus on CS within EECS here, I'd say it's actually an advantage. As you take more upper div EE classes, you'll find that you're learning from some of the best EE profs in the world in classes that are criminally small. If anything, everyone having their focus on CS allows you more of an opportunity to stand out in that you have the chance to talk to these profs in OH and can thus build meaningful relationships with them that can evolve naturally into research positions or letters of rec in the future. Getting into EE research here is orders of magnitude easier than getting into CS research as a result (I'd say), so choosing to take an EE-focused track here has plenty of benefits.

Agreed with the above comment - while it can be disheartening at times, you also end up with much smaller class sizes and closer relationships with professors (my technical classes this past semester had about 30 and 70 students respectively!), and you'll also find a tight peer group of those who share your interests.

It's funny that you ask this question because I basically felt the exact same way as you do now at the beginning of the semester that just finished. I'd heard terrible stories about how CS 70 is ridiculously difficult and impossible to "crack", so I was apprehensive to say the least. I took 70 with EE 105 and 130 and an easy humanities class, and, surprisingly, I'd say I had probably the most successful semester I'm likely to have at Cal. My high school prepared me pretty well for college-level physics and calculus, but I had very little to no exposure to probability before 70, and I can honestly say that 70 taught it much better than I expected (full credit to Babak) -- so much so that I'm inclined to take more stats classes in the future, perhaps in grad school. I'd say 70 is certainly a heavy-workload class (full disclosure: I took the test-only grading option and basically did the homework about 60% of the time, whenever 105 was not absolutely burning me alive), but its problems are of the kind of rigor that teaches you a lot if you put in the work. As for whether it's worthwhile or not, I feel that the only CS lower-div that has been more useful conceptually than 70 as an EE intern this summer has been 61C (basic programming aside-- I knew how to do that before 61AB). I work in optics and was presented with a datasheet describing the Gaussian nature of the intensity of light outputted by the lasers in our devices the third day of work and was blown away. So, yes, 70 is useful. And, for what it's worth, I enjoyed it more as a class than 61AB (though 61C was still my favorite CS lower div in terms of subject matter) and must say that the 70 staff is probably the best you will encounter at this (or maybe any) university. I'd also like to note that 16AB did feel like very good preparation for 70 as I went through it (even though I still found 70 very difficult), so I wouldn't be scared if it's preparation you're worried about.

history.content:
I'm majoring in EECS, but I'm only focusing on EE, is there any way I can get out of taking CS70? Lol

I'm being half sarcastic and serious. If I delay it long enough maybe the graduation requirements will change...
history.subject: Do I *have* to take CS70?
